awd_titl_txt: Multiphase Flow Dynamics of Blood Cells in Compliant Vessels: Towards A Computational Study of Autoregulation of Blood Flow in Microcirculation
awd_abstract_narration:
Blood pumped from the heart to various parts of the body is conveyed by a hierarchy of blood vessels. This vascular system supplies oxygen nutrients to cells in the body and removes carbon dioxide and metabolic waste. The terminal blood vessels are capillaries, and this is where gas and nutrient exchange with surrounding tissue takes place. Demand for oxygen and nutrients varies with time in specific tissues. For example, cerebral neurons demand more oxygen during increased cognitive activities. Each organ and tissue is able to regulate its blood supply on demand. Blood flow regulation at the capillary level is known as autoregulation, and it involves dilation and contraction of vessels triggered by smooth muscle cells (SMCs) in the pre-capillary vessel wall.  Autoregulation allows the capillaries to maintain constant blood flow rates despite sudden changes in pressure. Loss of autoregulation is associated with many pathological conditions, including dementia and coronary disease.  Compliance of blood vessels is the key to the process.  Red blood cells (RBCs) are extremely flexible; their motion through capillaries influences overall blood flow and pressure distributions, which in turn affect activation of pressure-sensitive SMCs. This project will develop a computational model of autoregulation of blood flow by combining RBC deformation, SMC activation, and vessel compliance. The model will provide a detailed understanding of the critical pathways that cause loss of autoregulation and its effects in various diseases such as dementia, stroke, heart disease, kidney failure. The project will involve mentoring graduate and undergraduate students in research, and will engage high-school students through a summer research program.

This project will develop a high-fidelity, three-dimensional, multiscale, multiphysics, fluid-structure interaction (FSI)-based computational model of autoregulation of blood flow in physiologically realistic vascular networks. It will integrate a coarse-grain bio-electro-chemical model for calcium ion-mediated active contractile stress generation in SMCs, finite-strain viscoelastic model for the dynamic response of the blood vessel walls, large deformation of flowing RBCs in suspension, and Immersed Boundary methods to couple the fluid flow with deforming interfaces. The influence of vessel compliance on RBC deformation and distribution, and the role of RBC rheology on vessel deformation will be analyzed quantitatively. The apparent viscosity of blood in compliant vessels, and the effects of vessel compliance on RBC partitioning at vascular bifurcations will also be addressed. Finally, the role of active contraction on the distribution of RBCs in a vascular network, and the role of RBC distribution on active contraction will be studied.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Healthy functioning of the body requires every cell getting the necessary oxygen ad nutrients. Red blood cells serve as the oxygen carrier and are driven by the pumping action of the heart. The transport of oxygen from red blood cells to tissues occurs in narrow blood vessels that have diameter in the range of micrometers. Red blood cells are highly flexible that allows them to smoothly flow through such microvessels. The microvessels, in turn, are also flexible. They inflate and deflate in response to cardiac rhythms. They can also actively dilate and contract to locally regulate flow in specific regions. Flexibility of the microvssels deteriorate with aging and many diseases, such as hypertension and dementia, affecting the flow of red blood cells and delivery of oxygen.

In this project, we developed a high-fidelity computational model based on the governing equations of fluid motion and constitutive models for cells and wall material to predict flow and large deformation of compliant vessels. We also developed an analytical theory to predict vessel deformation and flow. Our model predicted novel behavior of thin-walled hyperelastic vessels. Using the model, we studied the flow physics of a viscoelastic vessel in pulsatile flow and revealed new knowledge on hysteresis dynamics. We further simulated flow of deformable cells through deforming vessels and found that cells undergo sequence of highly complex shape changes that are not seen in rigid vessels. These results have implications for flow of red blood cells in healthy and diseased vessels. The methodology can also be extended to diverse problems, such as lung airway, lymphatic flow, and flexible microfluidics.

One PhD student was trained in the research that encompassed diverse fields. Two undergraduate students were also involved in related research to prepare them for higher education. A group of high school students were mentored to encourage them to pursue STEM education. Results were disseminated to the scientific community by journal publications and conference presentations. Results have been presented in undergraduate fluid mechanics, and multiphysics simulation courses, during engineering open houses, to motivate undergraduates and graduates to pursue computational modeling of complex and multidisciplinary research problems, and during recruitment events for undergraduates and graduate students. Results are also presented to high school students in Governor's school program.


Last Modified: 01/13/2025
Modified by: Prosenjit Bagchi
